title: Definition of Data
text:
Data can be defined as a :blue-background[unit of information]. 
Ok, but there's more to this simple definition. Think of data as the smallest social object, the basic building block used to create meaning. Data is social because it must already be encoded in a way that others can understand. For example, light itself is not data until it is measured and recorded.

title: What Requisites Must Data Have?
question_multiple: What are the key requisites that data must have?

explanations.Value: Data must have value, which represents its informational dimension. This means it must be encoded and decoded in a way that can be understood. Without this property, information cannot be communicated or interpreted effectively. In informational theory, value is what allows data to be usable and meaningful for further processing and analysis
explanations.Registry: Data must have a material dimension, meaning it needs to be recorded and stored in some form, whether digitally or physically. There is no such thing as ethereal data; even data in transit is represented as a signal. This registry ensures that data exists in a tangible form that can be retrieved and analyzed.
explanations.Number: Not all data needs to be numerical. While numbers can be data, other forms of data include text, images, and more.
explanations.Observation: Data must have a connection to reality. This can be through direct observation or derivation from existing data. Without a connection to reality, data is merely a random unit with no meaningful context. Even synthetic data, which is artificially generated, must be based on patterns and insights derived from real observations.

title: Dimensions of Data
text: :blue-background[Data is a social process that starts with an observation], grounding it in reality through measurements or recordings. Without observation, data is just a random number, disconnected from any real-world context. :blue-background[It must then hold value, embodying its informational dimension by being encoded in a way that can be decoded and understood]. Without value, it becomes meaningless symbols, failing to convey any information. Finally, :blue-background[data requires a registry, giving it a material dimension through proper recording and storage]. Without a registry, it remains ephemeral and cannot be retrieved or analyzed.

title: Digital Data
question: In what year was the first transistor invented?
explanations: The invention of the first transistor was a groundbreaking achievement in the field of electronics, :blue-background[developed by John Bardeen, Walter Brattain, and William Shockley at Bell Labs]. This pivotal innovation marked the onset of the semiconductor age and laid the :blue-background[foundation for the era of digital data]. Transistors enabled the creation and processing of digital data, which is :blue-background[characterized by its ability to be read and interpreted by machines]. This machine-readable data transformed various aspects of society, ushering in a :blue-background[new age of intelligibility].
